channel.title: EU drops Microsoft browser charges
channel.description:
BRUSSELS (AP) -- The European Union said Wednesday it is dropping antitrust charges against Microsoft Corp. after the company agreed to give Windows users a choice of up to 12 other Web browsers. Under the terms of the deal with regulators, Microsoft will avoid further EU fines if it provides a pop-up screen that lets European users -- from March -- replace Microsoft's Internet Explorer or add another browser such as Mozilla's Firefox or Google's Chrome. This will also allow computer manufacturers to ship PCs without Internet Explorer in Europe.
Lucky if you never even have to install IE.

item.title: EU drops Microsoft browser charges
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

A big part of the Windows users see IE as a part of the OS. They think they are forced to use IE, and completely freak out when they hear about leaks in IE. So to protect the Windows users, the EU wants the users to be able to choose a browser before they go online. The problem that arises is that most of those who don’t know much about computers see that IE is made by Microsoft, so they automatically pick IE because they put trust in company’s they know.

Read full topic

item.title: EU drops Microsoft browser charges
item.dc:creator: @Fat_Cookies Fat Cookies
item.description:
@Fat_Cookies wrote:

On the bottom line, Microsoft has a right to put whatever they want into their OS. IE exsists on windows(in usa) and it looks like it wont change. Yes it is the most horible browser known to mankind but we just have to live with it- it’s not like it uses any memory or cpu when you are not running it; it just uses about 1gb hard disk space. Ron, you are crying over spilt milk.

There are lots of things that are morally wrong but we just have to live with it.

I feel warm inside that I live in the uk and most of you guys don’t.

Read full topic

item.title: EU drops Microsoft browser charges
item.dc:creator: @Ron Ron
item.description:
@Ron wrote:

Just to clarify, Id rather debate than argue. Your statements sound borderline edgy and with a tone. So tone it down.

I’m aware those companies contribute and aren’t doing it solely for charitable purposes but hey, they got to make a living too. They only attach software that’s popular in the community for how great the program is not because gnome is making money off of spreading firefox or KDE for spreading conqueror. Linux is a democratic system whereas Windows is nazi germany without the efficiency.

Those nooby web browsers could be made with other software packages and could use Firefox’ gecko engine if they wanted to. Through convenience they stick with IE. I mean it’s already preinstalled, might as well use that. That’s what they’re thinking. I mean why should IE come preinstalled. What if Best Buys made it mandatory that everyone who bought a computer would have to make the choice of what browser you wanted preinstalled and gave pros/cons of each? Which would they chose? I mean maybe they should package IE and Firefox and when I say they, I mean Microsoft. But they wouldn’t do that. Why would they help out an OS community that they want destroyed? So they bundle it with IE.

So maybe canonical, red hat, ibm, sun, and many other companies who contribute to OS software have their own financial agenda, but why is Microsoft exempt from that? Their the ones making the largest profit. Why shouldn’t the other companies enjoy OS and contribute so they get a better working program through community collaboration?

~Ron

Read full topic

item.title: EU drops Microsoft browser charges
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

@Ron: Are you aware who contributes the most code to the large open source projects? I’m talking things like Xorg and the like. If you are, please explain why they should be exempt from this type of ruling. Why should Novell, Canonical and RedHat be exempt? I can assure you they are not some altruistic charities, they are a business who happens to provide open source software.

By the way, the Internet Explorer front-end could always be removed. All that was necessary was the rendering engine, which was plugginable to other applications (I’m sure you’ve seen the nubs making “web browsers” in VB by using it as an ActiveX control). Why shouldn’t MS make use of this engine in their own applications that require the ability to render web pages? It’s pretty much the only sane thing to do.

In fact, can you even offer ONE way in which they’ve been employing “harmful operational strategies”. It appears your answer is “I don’t like IE so nobody should.”

Read full topic

item.title: EU drops Microsoft browser charges
item.dc:creator: @Speljohan Speljohan
item.description:
@Speljohan wrote:

[quote=“Ron, post:13, topic:319912”]I applaud EU for being the first to do something about Microsoft’s harmful competition strategies by abusing its monopoly. @cumescape, most people are naive and don’t know how flawed IE is and have never even heard of Firefox/Opera/Chrome. So MS takes advantage of this and just ties it in labeling it as convenient and necessary for the operating system to function (only because they make it so).

Im running vista/linux on a dual boot and going to wipe off vista and install EU’s windows 7. Then I don’t have to worry about IE attached to the core of the operating system like an unnecessary detrimental leech on my system when and if I ever use windows again. Wine is just becoming that good.

@Mopman Linux is like an operating system wikipedia. Everyone contributes for the greater good - utilitarianism. There’s no need for anyone’s ego to get involved, it’s simply a collaboration of people who want to make the best, the fastest, and the securest system.

It’s fucking ridiculous that Microsoft can even have the power to make anyone conform to any software. I can highly respect the people of EU for forcing MS to remove their disgusting shit from the OS. Anyway, if you live in Europe and want IE that badly, you are still free to download it. You now have the freedom to not have it on your system. That’s all the people want, freedom.[/quote]One could argue why anyone would like to live in USA then. Also, why use Windows if you want freedom? That’s just ridiculous.

PS: IE in Vista and Win7 isn’t used for any internal components in the OS beside being a webbrowser, hence i see the EU as complete morons for doing this. It’s like telling a linux distro they can’t be shipped with OpenOffice “BECAUSE MICROSOFT OFFICE EXISTS AS WELL”.

Read full topic

@Mopman Linux is like an operating system wikipedia. Everyone contributes for the greater good - utilitarianism. There’s no need for anyone’s ego to get involved, it’s simply a collaboration of people who want to make the best, the fastest, and the securest system.

It’s fucking ridiculous that Microsoft can even have the power to make anyone conform to any software. imo, its such bullshit, and i don’t even like microsofts business practices. but how the hell can you call bundling a browser with your os (even if it is a terrible browser like IE) illegal?[/quote]Agree. It is quite fucking ridiculous.

item.title: EU drops Microsoft browser charges
item.dc:creator: @cumescape cumescape
item.description:
@cumescape wrote:

Microsoft said it will start sending updates in March to Windows computers in Europe so that when PC users log on, they will see a pop-up screen asking them to pick one or more of 12 Web browsers to download and install. People who buy new PCs will see the screen when they start up for the first time.
Why... When I format my XP Pro all I use IE for is downloading Firefox on 1st run, updating and porn. I don't how or why you could sue when you are able to install other internet browsers. If someone could clarify.

Its not like they have a block on installing other browsers.

Read full topic
